title: Girls’ basketball maintains hot streak against Gunn
content:
[caption id="attachment_127736" align="alignright" width="391"] Senior forward Skylar Burris passes the ball to the top of the key against rival Gunn Titans (7-6, 1-1).  Photo by: Noah Yuen[/caption] "If you want to win, box out!" Palo Alto High School girls' basketball (8-2, 2-0) head coach Scott Peters said to his team late in the fourth quarter of a De Anza League matchup against cross-town rivals Gunn High School (7-6, 1-1). The Vikings went on to win "Quad Night" 72-63. Junior guard Carly Leong and senior guard Lauren Koyama led the Vikings in scoring, pouring in 45 points combined. "I shot the ball pretty well in the first half because I had some open looks," Leong said. "We kept our mental composure when we were down and we kept persevering to push back and take the lead." The Vikings struggled to pull ahead in the first half, trailing by 5 points after the first period, but were able to stay composed and fight back to even out the score at 34 points heading into half-time. In a dominant third quarter where the Vikings outscored the Titans 25-14, Koyama and senior forward Skylar Burris were able to lock down Gunn defensively, which proved to be the deciding factor in the game. "Our main goal was to make it hard for them to shoot outside, and to cut down as many of their second shot opportunities as we could," Burris said. "We wanted to force them to drive and make it hard for them to score in the key." Despite the win, senior forward Maya Lathi believes that there is still improvement for the Vikings. "I'm proud of the way we pulled it together for the second half last night, but we didn't play our best," Lathi said. "If we continue to improve on both sides of the ball and work on rebounding, then I believe our team will go far."
Paly is preparing for its next league game 7pm on next Wednesday against Mountain View High School (9-3, 1-0) at Gunn High School.
excerpt: "If you want to win, box out!" Palo Alto High School girls' basketball (8-2, 2-0) head coach Scott Peters said to his team late in the fourth quarter of a De Anza League matchup against cross-town rivals Gunn High School (7-6, 1-1). The Vikings went on to win "Quad Night" 72-63.
author: Kasra Orumchian

title: Boys’ basketball obliterates Gunn Titans in lopsided matchup
content:
The Palo Alto High School boys’ basketball team (10-2, 2-0) dominated their cross-town rivals, the Gunn Titans (9-4, 0-2), Friday night, winning decisively, 80-50. Paly won the opening tip and junior forward Max Dorward raced down the floor for an easy layup, which set the tone for the rest of the game. The Vikings utilized their height advantage over the Titans to run cash in for easy points in the paint. In addition, they moved the ball early, leading to countless uncontested jumpers and a flurry of scoring to open the game. Although mostly disciplined and composed, the Vikings continue to struggle with careless turnovers. Coach Peter Diepenbrock was visibly upset after strings of unforced turnovers from the team. Paly was able to counter its carelessness with the ball by playing stingy defense and shutting the Titans down on offense. The Vikings took an early 19-6 lead after four minutes of play in the first quarter and never took their feet off the gas pedal. At the half, the Vikings led 47-29 and continued to pummel the under-sized Titan squad throughout the remainder of the game. Junior shooting guard Spencer Rojahn, who recorded eight points along with six rebounds for the Vikings, said the win is a great sign for the team moving forward. “This big win gives us confidence going into the season, but we need to be able to handle success and continue to work hard in practice,” Rojahn said. [caption id="attachment_127732" align="alignleft" width="311"] Junior center Bryant Jefferson attempts a free-throw late in the game against Gunn on Friday. The Vikings would go on to blow-out the Titans, 80-50. Photo: Maya Reuven.[/caption]
The Vikings stayed composed despite the large lead. Dorward led the Vikings with 20 points, seven rebounds, three assists and two steals, including 10 points in the first quarter. Senior guard Miles Tention chipped in with 10 points, four assists, three rebounds and three steals. Exceptional ball movement enabled 13 of  Paly’s 14 roster players to score either from the field or the free-throw line during the game. Dorward said he was impressed by the significant win margin, but the Vikings still have aspects of their game to study and work on. “We played well and I thought we exceeded our expectations, but we have to continue to improve,” Dorward said. “We will look at film to see what we have to work on, but we definitely have to cut down on our turnovers.” Paly held its ground defensively, limiting Gunn’s star player, senior Jeffrey Lee-Heidenreich to 11 points. Lee-Heidenrich was the Titans’ leading scorer heading into Friday's matchup. The Vikings hope to continue their undefeated De Anza League season against the Los Altos High School Eagles (7-5, 0-1) on Tuesday at Gunn High School.
excerpt: Friday night was a decided victory for the Palo Alto High School boys’ basketball team (10-2, 2-0), which dominated throughout the game against cross-town rivals, the Gunn Titans (9-4, 0-2), with an end score of 80-50.
author: Benner Mullin

title: Preview: Girls’ basketball aims to continue undefeated league play against Gunn
content:
[caption id="attachment_127667" align="aligncenter" width="560"] Senior forward Skylar Burris attacks the hoop against the Saratoga Falcons. "The key is teamwork and communication, which is something we've been working on all season", Burris said, as the Vikings went on to win the game, 81-46.
Photo By: Isabella Marcus[/caption] Following head coach Scott Peters' 200th win, the Palo Alto High School girls' basketball team (7-2, 1-0) aims to capture victory 201 by defeating crosstown rival Gunn High School (7-5, 1-0) on Friday at 6 p.m. at the Gunn gym. "Playing Gunn definitely adds to the pressure of tomorrows game," senior guard Lauren Koyama said. "We want to lead our school to victory against our rival. We have spent time preparing our game plan and are really pumped for Quad Night."
The Vikings have been preparing for Friday, according to senior forward Skylar Burris. "The key is teamwork and communication, which is something we've been working on all season," Burris said. "We're a very close team and being able to lean on each other during a big game is going to be important. We've been focusing on our defensive principles, and we want to make it as hard as possible for Gunn to score." The Vikings hope to carry its momentum forward from this weeks' first league win as it toppled Saratoga Falcons (9-4, 0-1)  in its league opener 81-46, with junior guard Carly Leong leading the Vikings with 23 points.
"We shot really well and hopefully we have a good shooting tomorrow night against Gunn," Leong said.
The Titans are also coming off a win in its league opener, as Gunn defeated the Wilcox Chargers (7-6, 0-1) 65-51.
excerpt: Following head coach Scott Peters' 200th win, the Palo Alto High School girls' basketball team (7-2, 1-0) aims to capture victory 201 by defeating crosstown rival Gunn High School (7-5, 1-0) on Friday at 6 p.m. at the Gunn gym.
author: Kasra Orumchian

title: Preview: Vikings shoot for revenge against Titans
content: "Cut off baseline! Help middle!" Palo Alto High School boys' basketball (9-2,1-0) head coach Peter Diepenbrock says as he commands the Vikings in the heat of play against league opponent Milpitas. Diepenbrock's fiery demeanor on the sideline exemplifies the energy the Vikings intend to carry over to the game on Friday. Coming off a 58-43 victory against Milpitas High School (4-9,0-1) on Tuesday, the Vikings are looking to play to their strengths against the Gunn High School Titans (9-3, 0-1) at 7:45 p.m. on Friday at the Gunn gym for "Quad Night". Paly hopes to continue to rely on junior starters forward Max Dorward and guard Jared Wulbrun, along with consistent ball movement on the court. Junior center William Schlemmer said the team didn't showcase its full potential during its first league game, despite receiving the win, and hopes that the team will come ready to play against its cross-town rivals. "I think my teammates and I are looking to perform much better on Friday," Schlemmer said.  "However, we should treat the Gunn game just like every other game because it shouldn't have to take a rivalry game to make us play our hardest." [caption id="attachment_127658" align="alignright" width="454"] Junior center William Schlemmer sinks a free-throw late in the Vikings' first home league game vs. Milpitas High School on Tuesday. Paly went on to defeat Milpitas with a final score of 58-43. Photo by Noah Yuen.[/caption] Some may remember the Titans giving Paly a run for their money during the 2015-16 season, beating the Vikings on Quad Night. However, Gunn lost its superstar, graduated senior Alex Gil-Fernandez, as well as senior Jonathan Davis,  a key role player on the team's starting lineup. Paly, on the other hand, lost sole senior forward Justin Hull, whose role was quickly filled by junior sharp shooter Jared Wulbrun. Diepenbrock said he hopes the team will play its own style of ball and keep Gunn's star player, 6'6" senior forward Jeffrey Lee-Heidenreich, off the boards. "The team is looking strong when [it is] able to play [its] style, which is pressing defensively full court and being aggressive in offensive transition," Diepenbrock said. "Gunn has a very good player, [Lee-Heidenreich]. We have to contain him and not let him get lots of offensive rebounds." Senior captain point-guard Miles Tention will once again assume his role as ball handler for the Vikings with support from fellow starters Schlemmer, Dorward, Wulbrun and junior guard Spencer Rojahn. Dorward, who has displayed himself as the team's most valuable player throughout the preseason and the first De Anza League game, hopes to avenge last year's loss and ensure that the Vikings finish at the top of the league. "This is a huge game because they are our cross-town rivals and we are looking for revenge from last year's loss," Dorward said. "I'm really excited for the opportunity to get another win and put ourselves in a good position to finish [at the] top of our league. The Paly Sixth Man Club instructs senior students to wear camouflage and remaining students to wear all green to showcase school spirit in the stands. Next up for the Vikings is a home game against the Los Altos Eagles this coming Tuesday, January 10th, and away against the Wilcox Chargers next Friday, January 13th.
excerpt: Coming off a 58-43 victory against Milpitas High School (4-9,0-1) on Tuesday, the Vikings are looking to play to their strengths against the Gunn High School Titans (9-3, 0-1) at 7:45 p.m. on Friday at the Gunn gym for "Quad Night". Paly hopes to continue to rely on junior starters forward Max Dorward and guard Jared Wulbrun, along with consistent ball movement on the court.
author: Noah Yuen

title: Girls’ basketball dominates Saratoga in league opener
content: [caption id="attachment_127670" align="alignright" width="385"] Senior forward Skylar Burris shoots a three in the second quarter of the game. "From the beginning we knew we wanted to get shots up quick in transition and I think we were able to do that well," Burris said. Photo by: Isabella Marcus[/caption] The Palo Alto High School girls' basketball team (7-2, 1-0) triumphed over the Saratoga High School Falcons (9-4, 0-1) in its De Anza League opener with a score of 81-46. The Vikings came out trigger happy, going on a 12-4 run in the first quarter, fueled by three-point shots from senior point guard Julie Chandler and senior guard Skylar Burris. "From the beginning, we knew we wanted to get shots up quick in transition, and I think we were able to do that well," Burris said. Paly built its point advantage early in the first quarter, giving it an 8-point lead heading into the second quarter. The Vikings continued to attack from the three point line, with sophomore shooting guard Ellie Jefferies and senior point guard Lauren Koyama both contributing to the continuous barrage from a distance. Koyama put the exclamation point on the lead, as she drilled a step back three point shot to end the half, sending the Vikings into the locker room with a 41-23 lead. "During a timeout, we decided to step up the intensity, and started hitting our shots, helping on defense more, and just getting our energy up," Koyama said. Junior guard Carly Leong carried the team in both the third and fourth quarters, scoring from all over the court. "Always shoot your shot especially when you are open," Leong said. "I was glad Ellie [Jefferies] had a bunch of threes in the first quarter. Hopefully that gained [helped her gain] more confidence so she shoots more because she is a great shooter." Leong's strong second half performance allowed the Vikings to coast to their first league victory of the season and head coach Scott Peter's 200th victory. "This win is going to set a precedent for the rest of the year; we need to go into every game with the same energy and the same grind mentality," Burris said. "Going into the game against Gunn, it'll be good to have this win under our belt. We are already super excited to play Gunn. It just adds to the building momentum." The Vikings will face off against cross-town rivals, the Gunn Titans (7-5, 1-0), at 6:15 p.m. on Friday at the Gunn gym for the infamous "Quad Night."
excerpt: The Palo Alto High School girls' basketball team (7-2, 1-0) triumphed over the Saratoga High School Falcons (9-4, 0-1) in its De Anza League opener with a score of 81-46.
author: Kasra Orumchian

title: Liveblog: Girls basketball takes on Saratoga
content:
Thank you for joining us on this fine evening as the Palo Alto High School girls' basketball takes on Saratoga.

[liveblog]

author: Isabella Marcus

title: Campus security cameras raise ethical questions
content: [caption id="attachment_123545" align="alignnone" width="600"] A camera overlooks the senior deck from the wall of room 109. Administrators installed 10 new surveillance cameras throughout Palo Alto High School over the summer break. Placed in  locations around major buildings and bike racks, the additional security is intended to reduce theft and vandalism, according to school administration. Photo by Sid Sharma.[/caption] Assistant Principal Jerry Berkson makes it part of his relatively new routine to check security camera footage whenever bike thefts are reported. Berkson, who until recently had limited tools to effectively catch perpetrators at Palo Alto High School, has proven to be considerably successful at identifying theft incidents on campus with the aid of ten new surveillance cameras. The footage has been visited five times as of October, and has helped successfully identify the perpetrators in three of the incidents, Berkson said. Despite their proven merit at catching thieves and school vandals, the use of these monitor devices brings up the question: Is what some see as the act of recording over 2,000 students and over 200 faculty members without clear student or board consent justified by the benefit of being able to prevent crime on campus? According to Berkson, the new cameras were originally installed to deter bike theft. The cameras were installed either near bike racks, to record the theft, or around a number of the campus's access points where the footage would show thieves entering or exiting the scene of the crime. According to Berkson, between the original conception of the idea to install cameras and the actual installation, the purpose of the cameras seemed to have changed. As several incidents of vandalism and campus streaking occurred with the new year, the devices proved to have other helpful purposes besides catching bike thieves. This map illustrates the location of the newly installed security cameras on campus. These do not include the cameras in the Media Arts Center  The Paly Voice counted that four of the 10 newly installed cameras are pointed at bike racks. The other six are generally pointed at popular student areas or outside the range of the bike racks, including in the Quad, and the large tree adjacent to the math building.  Not all bike racks have coverage either. The uncovered areas include the football field bike racks and the science building racks. According to campus supervisor Scott Reese, who has served the school for over 20 years, most bike thefts occur after school. A good thief may be equipped with an arsenal of advanced tools from bolt cutters to freon gas, a refrigerant used in air conditioning which freezes a sprayed-on surface in a matter of seconds, making frozen locks extremely brittle. For the best of these sinister specialists, it only takes 90 seconds or less to steal a bike, according to Reese. When The Paly Voice got access to some of the footage, courtesy of Berkson, as viewed at midnight, much of the it was simply impossible to comprehend, some was very visible, but some was occasionally too obscured by light glare to identify the perpetrator. “It's not the greatest quality of footage," Berkson said, explaining how the nighttime nature of most of these crimes creates one of the chief obstacles for the administration.   According to School Board member Heidi Emberling, the next-most-recent round of school board-approved cameras was installed a few years ago with the specific purpose of catching locker thieves .  School Board member Camille Townsend was not necessarily supportive of the newly added cameras. “We weren’t made aware of that [the cameras], " Townsend said. "For me, I’m not in support of surveillance unless there is a very specific purpose like, for example, straight on the lockers to dissuade locker theft.”  Ken Dauber, another school board member, said the cameras were well within the administration’s rights. "I think they [the surveillance cameras] fall into the scope of what the principal is allowed to decide," Dauber said. "I don't think the principal should have to come to the school board for approval." Ethics experts generally encourage schools to follow a set of guidelines when camera installation is involved. Attorney of school law Amy M. Steketee has written a number of ethical guidelines for District Administration Magazine. "Develop policies that set out the purpose for using surveillance cameras and outline the parameters for use," Skeketee stated in one of her articles. "Notify the school community-by including statements in student handbooks and posting signs-that surveillance cameras are located throughout school buildings and that anyone on school property may be videotaped." In line with this recommendation, the Paly administration has framed several notices throughout the school, informing passersby that cameras are watching them. [caption id="attachment_127414" align="alignnone" width="800"] "All Activities Monitored By Video Camera" reads one of 7 notice signs, placed on a pillar near the auto shop bike racks, in approximate distance to one of the ten cameras. These signs were added after the cameras went online, to abide by ethical regulations as per suggestion of the District Administration Magazine.[/caption] Surrounding school districts also abide by these same sets of rules. For example, Mountain View High School publishes signs on the campus and a warning in its student handbook. The handbook reads: "Surveillance cameras are in place in numerous areas on school property. Their purpose is for the protection of students, staff and property. Information obtained from camera recordings may be used in the investigation of school rule violations or criminal activity." As for Steketee's suggestion to include statements in the school handbook, there is no mention of the cameras in the 86-page Paly student handbook this year, and no parent or student consent, nor board approval, was received for the devices at the time of installation according to Emberling and Townsend. The footage that is not filmed in the MAC is easily accessible by administrators on their laptops, phones, or tablets through the Alibi interface. The MAC footage is stored on the DVR in the control room of the MAC. According to students on the robotics team, last year, students were able to get access to the wood shop camera footage because the administration linked a live stream of the camera footage on one of the district's public websites. The link has since been removed. "Some people I know found a way to access a camera around the wood shop online," senior Gregory Jerian said. They were able to take snapshots of what was going on around the bike cages in front of the science building." The installation of the cameras did not affect the insurance rate of the school, according to Berkson. Often insurance companies will offer lower rates if their client installs cameras. The rationale is that fewer things will be stolen, meaning the insurance company will have to pay less in possible damages. The installation is indicative of a larger trend of increased surveillance in schools. A 2008-9 Justice Department report found that use of security cameras in public schools was nearly 50 percent nationwide, while according to a report by the National Center for Education Statistics camera surveillance in public schools rose to 89 percent by the 2013-2014 school year.  The Fourth Amendment, which usually protects people from unlawful search and seizure, does not uniformly apply to students at school. Courts have upheld surveillance in public areas and suspicion-less searches such as drug tests constitutional. After several months of being in active use, the cameras have been proven effective at catching bike theft and vandalism incidents. Yet according to Reese, the number of thefts this year has stayed consistent with last year when cameras were not installed.
excerpt: Several new small, inconspicuous cameras have come online in the past few weeks to help the Palo Alto High School administration patrol the campus.
author: Donnesh Farmanfarmaian

title: Stage tech: The unseen side of theater
content: The bright lights, dazzling costumes and vivid sets, part of every theater production, are essential in transporting audiences to other worlds in which dramatic stories, played out by Palo Alto High School’s talented actors and actresses, can seem life-like. But, behind the scenes, students dressed in all black are busy making the whole production possible, and without them, the show would not go on. These students are members of Paly’s stage tech program, which handles everything from lighting to costumes to sets, according to senior Edward Park. “What stage tech, or stage crew, does in the shows is anything that isn’t just the actors on stage,” Park said. “All the audio things [...], all the props, that’s stuff that our class puts together to supplement the actors doing their show.” While this is Park’s fourth year working with stage tech at Paly, he has been working behind the scenes for much longer. “I started doing tech in 6th grade with Ms. Gray at Jordan,” Park said. “And then as time went on I came to Paly and I did tech here, and I’ve also been working productions outside of school at community theaters in the Bay Area.” Once Park came to Paly, he joined the eighth period stage tech class. The majority of students involved in Paly stage tech are also a part of this once-per-week class. “It [the class] is Mondays after school for two hours, and that’s the only time we meet,” Park said. “The only real requirement in it is that you work at least 75 hours a semester, which is easy enough if you run a show, come to every class, and come to a couple of the work days.” Once a part of the program, a student is faced with the many fields of stage tech, including sound, light, set building, props, hair, makeup, costumes and more. With so many options to chose from, many try multiple fields until they find their main focus, while others know from the beginning. “There are definitely people like me who focus on one thing; I’ve been focusing on sound since I was a freshman,” Park said. “There are some people who work in multiple fields, like there are a couple of sophomores and freshmen who work in sound and lights and set, and a couple of people do hair, makeup and costuming as well as some sound work or some crew work here and there.” After a couple years of getting a feel for the vast variety offered by stage tech, students are encouraged to hone in one skill. “We do recommend that eventually, by junior year, you do choose one thing to focus on, so that you can get proficient at it and start teaching the incoming class of underclassmen,” Park said. “But overall, if you really want to be a jack of all trades, that’s entirely fine.” Park has focused on sound since his freshman year, and is currently the head of the sound group. “What I do in stage tech right now is I supervise the microphone and the audio work of every actor and stage technician that there is,” Park said. According to Park, his favorite part of the stage tech program is the close-knit bond between the stage crew and the actors. “I never did any of the sports programs, I’m a part of the music program,” Park said. “But the community I get from stage tech is great because not only am I working with the crew, I’m working with the actors.” While Park prioritizes audio work, junior Gail Hildebrand has focused on props since her sophomore year. “I became props master when the previous props master, Charlotte Moffat [...] was a senior my sophomore year, I took over for her for a couple of the shows,” Hildebrand said. Hildebrand acquires props for a show by borrowing, renting or even reusing old props, but she prefers creating the props herself. “I would probably choose to be ‘props designer’ more than ‘props master’, because that’s more the creation of things,” Hildebrand said. Hildebrand looks forward to the production of "Beauty and the Beast", because she will have the chance to get creative and incorporate elements of props that she enjoys. “I’m hoping I’ll be able to help with a lot of the props for that "Beauty and the Beast" because they’ll be more old-timey themed and that’s the stuff that I like,” Hildebrand said. According to Hildebrand, her favorite part of working on props is seeing the final product on stage at a show. “It’s really cool to see everyone’s creative ideas and how they all come together,” Hildebrand said. “Everyone has their own, unique ideas, but when you put them all together it makes a consistent, really cool show.” In addition to props, Hildebrand does set building. While her experiences in the two fields have been different, they complement each other other well. “Build is really nice because it’s very informal,” Hildebrand said. “At least to me, you just sort of show up, and they just hand you tools and explain how to use them. I went into it not even knowing how to use a drill, and now I feel confident using jigsaws. That is definitely an improvement for me, and I think it helps with props as well, because I know how to build stuff, if I need to.” Hildebrand has found that the transition from the Haymarket theater to the newly constructed Performing Arts Center has caused some changes in set building. “Now that we have the new theater, we have to have [to build] much larger sets,” Hildebrand said. After working in the Haymarket theater for three years, Park has also had to readjust to the different equipment in the PAC. According to Park, the biggest difference between the Haymarket and the PAC is the new state of the art equipment. “There are a lot of issues at the Haymarket that come just from age,” Park said. “A lot of cabling as well as the hardware that we have is so old that we’re gonna have problems no matter what we try and fix it. And of course we try and fix it, like all the white noise and all the stage issues that we had. We have always tried to fix that. That isn’t an issue with this theater and all the hardware that we have. What we’re working with is new, so we know there aren’t any developmental faults with it. And we’ve learned how to use it better.” Park encourages those interested to join the program and participate in the unique experience that stage tech has to offer. “The Paly stage tech program, or the Paly theater program as a whole, is probably one of the most professional high school programs that you can come and work with. [...]” Park said.  “That being said, that does mean that we’re a slightly more serious environment than some other high school programs and I can see how that might be a bit frightening to some people who’ve never experienced or done this kind of thing before. But regardless of how intense we are, we’re always inclusive of new people and if you’re coming in ready to learn, that’s all we need.”
excerpt: The bright lights, dazzling costumes, and vivid sets part of every theater production are essential in transporting captivated audiences to other worlds in which dramatic stories, played out by Palo Alto High School’s talented actors and actresses, can seem life-like. But behind the scenes, students dressed in all black are busy making the whole production possible, and without them, the show would not go on.
author: Maya Akkaraju

title: Boys’ soccer dominates Sequoia in final minutes
content:
[caption id="attachment_127471" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Palo Alto High School senior Michel Ange Siaba fights a Carlmont High School soccer player during a preseason match on Nov. 30. The Vikings won their third preseason game, 2-1. Photo: Emma van der Veen.[/caption] With 30 minutes left on the clock, neither the Palo Alto High School (7-1-0) nor Sequoia High School (1-2) boys’ soccer teams had scored on one another. But in the span of three minutes, the Vikings scored two goals to defeat Sequoia 2-0 yesterday at Paly. 

After a devastating loss against Burlingame High School last Thursday, where the Vikings fell 0-1, the Vikings proved their dominance on the field with a resounding win.

The first of the Vikings' goals broke a 0-0 tie in the 50th minute. All eyes were on Viking sophomore left forward Isaiah Schoenberger, who drove the ball through two Sequoia defenders working off a clean cut pass from senior forward and keeper Michel Ange Siaba.

As Schoenberger scored the first goal of the game, senior fan Andrew Vargha cheered from the stands louder than the crowd of parents present.

What followed was another goal by senior defender Thomas Crouch, who worked off a pass from senior captain Neil Verwillow. With Paly’s sudden 2-0 lead, the Cherokee's  play became more aggressive. In a sudden turnaround, Sequoia regained possession and drove the ball back towards the Paly goal. Four Sequoia players positioned themselves near the Paly goal as Paly defenders sprinted into action. Sequoia took shot towards the upper left of the goal, but  junior keeper Kiran Misner jumped and punched the ball. The ball shot high up and for a few seconds it looked as though it would fly back into the Paly goal, but Misner's block pushed the ball far enough that it landed behind the goal net. Safe.

Misner recalls the shift in dynamic following the two goals and the close save.

“Our team definitely came alive in the second half and I think that was partly due to some of the tactical changes we made going into the second [half] and also because our team kept on pushing for that first and then second goal,” Misner said. “As for the save, I didn’t really think too much about it and relied on my reflexes to get a hand on it."

Players look forward to their final preseason game, which will be an alumni game at 3:30 p.m. on Dec. 29, at home, before entering the regular season.
excerpt: With 30 minutes left on the clock, neither the Palo Alto High School (7-1-0) nor Sequoia High School's (1-2) boys’ soccer team had scored on one another.  But in the span of three minutes, the Vikings scored two goals to defeat Sequoia 2-0 yesterday at Paly.
author: Bianca Al-Shamari

title: Students halfway to qualifying for ‘Tournament of Champions’ debate
content: [caption id="attachment_127253" align="alignright" width="472"] Senior debater Colin Fee (left) and junior debater Barry He (right) passionately discuss their debate successes and excitement for their bright futures.[/caption] Two Palo Alto High School students have qualified for what is known as the “World Cup” of high school debate: the Tournament of Champions.  Junior debater Barry He and senior debater Colin Fee each received one of the two necessary bids to qualify for the tournament on December 2 at the Alta silver and black invitational in Salt Lake City, Utah. He and Fee compete in the National Circuit, under the administration of the University of Kentucky, which requires them to travel around the country to various tournaments. This recently brought them to the Alta tournament in Utah, where both students received “bids” that bring them one step closer to a coveted spot in the TOC, a tournament that, according to He, only roughly 100 student debaters participate in. Students receive bids based on their performances in previous tournaments, many of which are out of the area and even out of state. Both students performed exceptionally well in their previous tournament, which Fee credits to their personal connection to their topics. “This debate tournament went pretty well, since we both went pretty far,” Fee said. “But more importantly was both of us writing about ourselves. Barry talked about the myth of the model minority and I dealt with the death of Ronald Armstrong, a disabled man who was killed in police brutality. That’s where I think the power of debate is, in becoming a self-advocate and finding yourself.” He and Fee compete in progressive debate, which is a national fast-paced debate format.  “The national circuit has a steep learning curve, since we do progressive debate, we don’t debate persuasively in front of parents,” He said. “It’s very common to see people at up to 450 words per minute on the circuit and reading obscure philosophy and critical theories while using a lot of debate jargon.” To keep up with the high level of competition, practice is a must for He and Fee. “I wasted three years of my life abandoning a social life,” Fee said. “It felt like a lot of hard work to finally reach this benchmark.” As their place in the TOC is not yet confirmed, He and Fee will be preparing  to earn a second bid at their upcoming tournaments. They will be debating  on Dec. 17 and 18 in the College Prep Invitational in Oakland, as well as on Jan. 6 at the University of Puget Sound in Tacoma, Washington.  “It just makes me hungry to do more and work harder so that I can go even further,” Fee said.
excerpt: This exclusive competition is just as prestigious, if not more, as it sounds.
author: Maya Reuven
